The ability and inclination to make choices that stand
 
The ability and inclination to make choices that stand
−
the test of time. To say that a choice was wise implies that the action or inaction was strategically correct when judged by some set of values. Another formulation is "Making the best use of available knowledge."
+
the test of time. To say that a choice was wise implies that the action or inaction was strategically correct when judged by some set of values. Another formulation is "Making the best use of available [[knowledge]]."
     
It is crucial to realize that a wise decision must often be made from incomplete information. This requires the chooser to know the way that situations (of any sort) usually turn out. Thus a wise decision must be corrent and justified, but the justification need not be based on a true belief.
